Prompt:
Example 1:
As Johnson worked on math problems with the other female computers, she would ask questions. She didn't want to just do the work — she wanted to know the "hows" and the "whys," and then the "why nots." By asking questions, Johnson began to stand out.
Women were not allowed to attend meetings with the male engineers and scientists. Johnson wanted to go to these meetings to learn more about the projects, so she went. She became known for her training in geometry and began to work with teams made up of men. Eventually, she was recognized as a leader, and the men increasingly relied on her to have the answers they needed.
In 1958, NACA officially became NASA. Shortly thereafter, Johnson became part of the space team. She began calculating the flight path, or trajectory path, for the rocket to put the first American in space in 1961. That American was astronaut Alan Shepard. The engineers knew when and where they wanted Shepard's space capsule to land, but the tricky part was to calculate when and where the rocket would have to launch. Johnson figured it out!

Example 2:
When Naomi saw that Ruth loved her so much, she forgot how tired and hungry she was, and the two journeyed on together until they came to Bethlehem in Judah in the beginning of the barley harvest. There was no famine in Bethlehem. The fields were full of waving grain, and busy servants were reaping it and gathering it up to bind into sheaves. Above all were the fields of the rich man, Boaz, shining with barley and corn.
Naomi and Ruth came to the edge of the fields and watched the busy reapers. They saw that after each sheaf was bound, and each pile of corn was stacked, a little grain fell, unnoticed, to the ground. Ruth said to Naomi: "Let me go to the field and glean the ears of corn after them." And Naomi said to her, "Go, my daughter." And she went, and came and gleaned in the field after the reapers.

Here is an example of a paragraph:

As I looked up at the stars on a clear night, I began to wonder about the world beyond our own. The night sky was full of twinkling lights, and I knew that there was so much more to learn about them. I asked my teacher about the planets, and she explained that they were massive balls of rock and gas that orbited around the sun. She told me that some planets were hot and dry, while others were cold and icy. I was fascinated by the idea of other worlds existing beyond our own, and I wanted to learn more. I began to read books and watch documentaries about astronomy, and I even started to use a telescope to gaze at the stars. The more I learned, the more I realized how much I didn't know, and I was eager to continue exploring the wonders of the universe. Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'astronomy' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 150 words.  
Astronomy is the study of the stars and planets in the universe. Scientists who specialize in astronomy are called astronomers. They observe the stars and planets to learn more about their movement and properties. Some astronomers study the stars to learn about their age and how they were formed. Others study the planets to learn about their atmosphere and the possibility of life existing on them. Astronomers use special equipment like telescopes and cameras to observe the stars and planets. They also study the light that comes from the stars to learn about their composition. Astronomers often work in observatories, which are special buildings that are designed to let astronomers study the stars and planets in a quiet and dark environment. By studying the stars and planets, astronomers can gain a better understanding of the universe. This helps them to answer questions and make new discoveries.

Astronomy is the study of the universe and everything in it. When you look up at the stars on a clear night, you are seeing what astronomy is all about. Scientists study the stars, planets, and galaxies to learn about their size, shape, and movement. They want to know how the universe was created and how it works. By using special tools like telescopes, scientists can see things in space that are too far away to be seen with the naked eye. They can also study the light from distant stars to learn about their temperature and composition. By answering these questions, scientists can gain a deeper understanding of the universe and its many mysteries. This helps us to better understand our place in the universe.

Prompt:
Example 1:
As Johnson worked on math problems with the other female computers, she would ask questions. She didn't want to just do the work — she wanted to know the "hows" and the "whys," and then the "why nots." By asking questions, Johnson began to stand out.
Women were not allowed to attend meetings with the male engineers and scientists. Johnson wanted to go to these meetings to learn more about the projects, so she went. She became known for her training in geometry and began to work with teams made up of men. Eventually, she was recognized as a leader, and the men increasingly relied on her to have the answers they needed.
In 1958, NACA officially became NASA. Shortly thereafter, Johnson became part of the space team. She began calculating the flight path, or trajectory path, for the rocket to put the first American in space in 1961. That American was astronaut Alan Shepard. The engineers knew when and where they wanted Shepard's space capsule to land, but the tricky part was to calculate when and where the rocket would have to launch. Johnson figured it out!

Example 2:
When Naomi saw that Ruth loved her so much, she forgot how tired and hungry she was, and the two journeyed on together until they came to Bethlehem in Judah in the beginning of the barley harvest. There was no famine in Bethlehem. The fields were full of waving grain, and busy servants were reaping it and gathering it up to bind into sheaves. Above all were the fields of the rich man, Boaz, shining with barley and corn.
Naomi and Ruth came to the edge of the fields and watched the busy reapers. They saw that after each sheaf was bound, and each pile of corn was stacked, a little grain fell, unnoticed, to the ground. Ruth said to Naomi: "Let me go to the field and glean the ears of corn after them." And Naomi said to her, "Go, my daughter." And she went, and came and gleaned in the field after the reapers.

In the beginning, there was darkness. The stars and planets were not visible. Then, a giant explosion occurred, known as the Big Bang. It released a huge amount of energy that formed all the stars and planets in the universe. The explosion was so powerful that it is still felt today. Astronomers study the universe to learn more about the Big Bang and the stars and planets that were created. They use special tools, like telescopes, to look at the stars and planets. They can see the stars and planets that are far away and learn about their properties. By studying the universe, astronomers can understand how the universe was formed and how it has changed over time. The universe is a fascinating place to learn about. Scientists continue to study it to learn more about its secrets.

Astronomy is the study of the stars, planets, and galaxies. For centuries, people have looked up at the night sky and wondered about the mysteries of the universe. They have asked questions like, "What is out there?" and "How do the stars move?" By studying the movement of the stars and planets, scientists can figure out the answers to these questions. Astronomers have learned that the universe is made up of billions of galaxies, each with billions of stars. They have also discovered that some stars are far away, while others are close to home. By studying astronomy, scientists can gain a better understanding of the universe and its many mysteries. It's a field of study that is full of wonder and discovery. As you look up at the night sky, you can be a part of this wonder and discovery too.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'astronomy' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 150 words. 

Astronomers are scientists who study the universe and the objects in it. They look at stars, planets, and galaxies to learn more about how the universe works. In the past, astronomers used telescopes to look at the night sky. Today, they use computers to study the stars and planets. By using computers, astronomers can make detailed pictures of the stars and planets, and even learn about new objects that are too small or too far away to see with the naked eye. Astronomers want to know more about the universe, so they keep studying and learning. As they discover more about the universe, they share their findings with the world, so everyone can learn and understand more about the stars and planets that we see in the sky. Astronomers are curious and love to learn. They ask questions and seek answers about the universe. By doing so, they make new discoveries that help us understand the world around us.
